species_list: Acer rubra, Quercus rubra, Pinus strobus, Tsuga canadensis
study_scale: 100's of plots, flux towers, and warming experiment data at Harvard Forest ( long-term ecological research site), in four different locations collectively covering ~ 40 km2,
growth_metric: NEP (net ecosystem production, calculated from flux towers)
gs_start_metric: Onset ecosystem productivity (first day daily NEP crosses 30% of maximum - from fluxnet data)
gs_end_metric: End ecosystem productivity (first day daily NEP goes below 30% of maximum - from fluxnet data)
ifyes_whichendogenous: differences in relationship between SOS and spring NEP due to species composition of the site
excellent_study: no - not for our purposes. They were interested in understanding the carbon budget and how it changed over time in Harvard Forest, so they did end up pulling together a lot of data relevant to this question. They did test for relationships between spring / autum GS and spring / autumn NEP, and both relationships suggest longer growing seasons lead to greater NEP. They also compiled tree ring records and assessed whether warmer months lead to greater ringwidth for two species.
big_problems: They used fluxnet data to derive both growth and gs metrics
missing_something_major: I wish they had directly quantified the relationship between growing season length (as they defined from NEP) and GPP, they assumed it from time-GPP and time-GSL, as well as SOS spring NEP and EOS autumn NEP relationships… They also had some information on SOS and EOS from long-term phenological observations of 9 trees, and I think they could have done more with that if they also had growth rates (see page 10, figs. 9 and 11)
gslxgrowthsimple: not measured x putative C assimilation

species_list: Pinus sylvestris (Scots pine), Norway spruce (Picea abies), Downy birch (Betula pubescens), European beech (Fagus sylvatica), European oak (Quercus robur), Betula pendula (Silver birch). First three species were used for tree ring analyses, all species for phenology assessment, but birch data merged.
study_scale: All of Sweden (phenological observations); latitudinal transect in northern half of Sweden (tree ring chronologies)
study_level: merged individuals within sites across year
rep_number: For tree ring data: 4, 3, and 10 chronologies (each chronology with an unspecificied number of individual trees cored) for Norway spruce, Betula pubescens, and Pinus sylvestris (respectively). Phenology data: 13633 observations between 1873-1951 collected at 634 locations and 18555 observations collected between 2008-2021 at 6867 locations. Table A1 and A2 have replicates
ifyouthink_no_why: several reasons - they didn't correlate their GS metrics (from phenology observations) with their growth metrics (from tree cores), and they standardized their growth metrics (from cores)
big_problems: They standardized the tree ring data (typical dendro) making it difficult to assess relationships between temperature and growth. They also never correlated their GS metrics with growth
missing_something_major: yes. they measured phenology and compared it to tree ring data, but because they 1) used different species across phenology and tree ring components; and 2) did not use raw ring widths (instead using detrended indices that were correlated with different month's temperatures, rather than growing season length)
notes: Interestingly, they find that the shifts in autumn phenology are much more variable and in many cases different than expected (shifts to earlier senescence rather than later). While these impacts are not as large as effects on budburst, so that GSL based on phenology is increasing as expected, it does suggest some sort of constraint, external or endogenous, on GSL that presumably would also impact growth.
notes_specific_columns: species_num & species_list: they looked at tree ring data for 3 species and phenology data for 6 species (the same three species + 3 others)
gslxgrowthsimple: vegtative phenology x radial growth

First three species were used for tree ring analyses, all species for phenology assessment, but birch data merged.

While these impacts are not as large as effects on budburst, so that GSL based on phenology is increasing as expected, it does suggest some sort of constraint, external or endogenous, on GSL that presumably would also impact growth.

species_list: Aesculus hippocastanum, Betula pendula, Fagus sylvatica, Quercus robur, Larix decidua, Sorbus aucuparia
rep_number: 434,226 observations, 14626 individual time series between 1948 and 2015 (see supplement for number of time series per species)
growth_metric: photosynthesis (total growing-season net daytime photosynthesis, modelled)
ifyouthink_no_why: they did not explore link between GSL and growth, instead, looked at the relationship between photosynthetic activity (growth), spring phenology, and autumn senesence. So they really did not explore how GSL influenced productivity (although they could have) and because they used photosynthetic activity as a explanatory variable for the response variable autumn senescence
ifyes_whichendogenous: greater photosynthesis early in the growing season is associated with earlier senescence
excellent_study: no - there are some really interesting patterns (this was really similar to the Zohner paper) but their main question was not related to how GS metrics affected growth, and seemed a bit circular (how does early season phenology affect late season phenology, how does productivity affect late season phenology)
big_problems: We weren't sure about assumptions of photosynthesis model.
missing_something_major: We  really wished they had looked at the entire length of the growing season rather than just autumn senescence, and related GSL to their growth / photosynthesis measure (rather than photosynthesis and early season phenology to autumn senescence - this seems odd).
notes: check fig. 1 in the paper
gslxgrowthsimple: not measured x putative C assimilation

big_problems: They did not measure budburst although they could have.

species_list: Abies alba, Acer pseudoplatanus, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Ilex aquifolium, Quercus petraea
study_scale: seeds on average from 9 provenances for each species (ranging from 6-13 depending on species) located along 2 elevational gradients in the Pyrenees (French side), planted in 1 common garden at sea level in SW France
authorsthink_ALTinfo:: they found that GSL had either no significant relationship (n=2) or a positive relationship with growth (n=2), depending on the species; only tested for 4 spp
ifyes_whichendogenous: provenance. Specifically they found evidence that provenances differed in both growth and phenology, but they did not test the gsl x growth (table 3) at the provenace level
excellent_study: yes - they are one of the few studies that actually correlated gsl and growth!
big_problems: no
missing_something_major: In an ideal world, it would have been cool to replicate their common garden in a lot of different places, so they could explore how climatic differences (across sites) interact with local adaptation (provenance) to climate to control growth. Or manipulating climate with warming and watering, to explose the same provenances to longer growing seasons and / or differences in water availability would also have been cool
notes_specific_columns: gsl_metric: The authors conducted tests using GSL, but also conducted separate tests using leafout and sensecne as explanatory variables. We have not entered these as separate rows, but these could be.
gslxgrowthsimple: vegtative phenology x biomass height stems

growth_metric: NPP (from InTEC - integrated terrestrial ecosystem carbon budget)
gs_all_metrics_described: no (they say NPP is estimated from spring temperature records, and projected changes to spring temperature for climate change, but the relationships between these is unclear. Could be suitable days?)
gs_metric_used: time with growth estimated (from mar-may temperature records)
authorsthink_ALTinfo:: The authors used their model (which includes temperature, n-deposition, CO2 and disturbance as explanatory variables for NPP) to calculate the contribution of climate change / a warmer spring on NPP, and found that NPP & carbon balanace had increased due to climate change.
ifyouthink_no_why: their results are based on an ecosystem model. While that model was parameterized with a lot of data (e.g. time series of temperature, CO2, etc), the underlying link between temperature (growing season from their point of view) and NPP is based on the model - which includes assumptions about how climate, N and CO2 (positively) contribute to photosynthesis (Farquhar model), and how other factors (disturbance) reduce it.
excellent_study: no - but our question wasn't the goal of their study
big_problems: it wasn't really explained well enough to fully assess the assumptions and data
missing_something_major: This study wasn't super relevant to our specific question, so not much to say here (without asking for a whole scale change in the entire study).
gslxgrowthsimple: climate and date x putative C assimilation

country: global, but phenology data mainly from Germany, Switzerland, Austria

ifyes_whichexternal: autumn temperature, winter chilling, spring temperature
big_problems: does not include effects of end of season changes on NPP in analysis or forecasting

gslxgrowthsimple: vegtative phenology x putative C assimilation

country: 21 sites mostly in Europe and North America
study_scale: 21 fluxnet sites mostly located in Europe, Northern America (one in Japan, one in Russia)
gs_start_satellite: greenup from MODIS 1km2 and JRC 36 km2 (date first achieved a particular threshold)
gs_end_satellite: senescence from MODIS 1km2 and JRC 36 km2 (date last achieved a particular threshold)
authorsthink_ALTinfo:: I'm reporting on the test they performed based on spatial relationships (site differences). They also explored the effects of the start and end of the growing season on temporal variation (see Table 3, Fig 6)
ifyes_whichendogenous: species composition and lagged productivity effects. Specifically, NEP of ENF, evergreen needle leaved forests was less sensitive to earlier SOS and later EOS than that of DBF, deciduous broadleaved forests. Additionally, they found stronger relationships when looking at spatial differences in growing season metrics / NEP than when looking at temporal variation. Finally, there were carry over effects such that an anomoly in GEP in one year resulted in an anomoly in GEP in the next nest year.
big_problems: no
missing_something_major: They used a lot of different indices of growth and growing season length, but never pulled it all together to test GSL by whole summer ecosystem productivity
notes: We was difficult to know how many rows to enter - they performed 22 tests across two types of forests (growing season start vs. end, derived from satellite, fluxnet and temperature, across sites and across years). We chose to focus on spatial variation in the start of the growing of the growing season, measured in two different ways (satellite, fluxnet), AND temporal variation tested using temperature metrics. We described other responses (largely consistent) in gs_metric_other, and reported on site differences and spatial vs. temporal differences in endogenous factors
notes_specific_columns: for column gs_start_metric - this is from 2 types of satellite data (date half greenup or half senescence based on fitted functions to MODIS and JRC data)
gslxgrowthsimple: not measured x putative C assimilation

study_scale: 21 fluxnet sites mostly located in Europe, Northern America (one in Japan, one in Russia)
gs_start_metric: fluxnet derived - first date NEP exceeds a threshold
gs_end_metric: fluxnet derived - last date NEP exceeds a threshold
authorsthink_ALTinfo:: This test is based on spatial relationships (site differences). They also explored the effects of the start and end of the growing season on temporal variation (see Table 3, Fig 6)
ifyes_whichendogenous: species composition and lagged productivity effects. Specifically, NEP of ENF, evergreen needle leaved forests was less sensitive to earlier SOS and later EOS than that of DBF, deciduous broadleaved forests. Additionally, they found stronger relationships when looking at spatial differences in growing season metrics / NEP than when looking at temporal variation. Finally, there were carry over effects such that an anomoly in GEP in one year resulted in an anomoly in GEP in the next nest year.
big_problems: They used fluxnet data to derive both growth and gs metrics
missing_something_major: They used a lot of different indices of growth and growing season length, but never pulled it all together to test GSL by whole summer ecosystem productivity
notes: We was difficult to know how many rows to enter - they performed 22 tests across two types of forests (growing season start vs. end, derived from satellite, fluxnet and temperature, across sites and across years). We chose to focus on spatial variation in the start of the growing of the growing season, measured in two different ways (satellite, fluxnet), AND temporal variation tested using temperature metrics. We described other responses (largely consistent) in gs_metric_other, and reported on site differences and spatial vs. temporal differences in endogenous factors
notes_specific_columns: for column gs_start_metric and gs_end_metric, this is fluxnet derived (first or last date NEP or GEP exceeded a specific absolute or relative threshold)

country: 21 sites mostly in Europe and North America
study_scale: 21 fluxnet sites mostly located in Europe, Northern America (one in Japan, one in Russia)
rep_number: 153 site-years (21 sites with 5-10 years per site)
gs_start_metric: temperature derived - first date GSI metric is a proportion of maximum
gs_end_metric: temperature derived - last date GSI metric is a proportion of maximum
ifyouthink_no_why: they did not test GSL, and the GS_end_metric results could nullify early season results. They tested the relationship between NEP early and late season and GSI early and late metrics. Although they found a significant relationship between spring warmth and NEP accumulation in early summer, they did not find a significant relationship for late season fluxes AND the coefficient is negative.
ifyes_whichendogenous: species composition and lagged productivity effects. Specifically, NEP of ENF, evergreen needle leaved forests was less sensitive to earlier SOS and later EOS than that of DBF, deciduous broadleaved forests. Additionally, they found stronger relationships when looking at spatial differences in growing season metrics / NEP than when looking at temporal variation. Finally, there were carry over effects such that an anomoly in GEP in one year resulted in an anomoly in GEP in the next nest year.
big_problems: no
missing_something_major: They used a lot of different indices of growth and growing season length, but never pulled it all together to test GSL by whole summer ecosystem productivity
notes: We was difficult to know how many rows to enter - they performed 22 tests across two types of forests (growing season start vs. end, derived from satellite, fluxnet and temperature, across sites and across years). We chose to focus on spatial variation in the start of the growing of the growing season, measured in two different ways (satellite, fluxnet), AND temporal variation tested using temperature metrics. We described other responses (largely consistent) in gs_metric_other, and reported on site differences and spatial vs. temporal differences in endogenous factors
notes_specific_columns: for gs_start_metric and gs_end_metric, used GSI - a metric calculated from minimum temp, photoperiod, evaporative demand (start is the date half maximum predicted to occur, end is the last date half maximum predicted to occur)
gslxgrowthsimple: not measured x putative C assimilation

rep_number: 15-17 years across 15459 pixels (2001-2018 MODIS data, 500 m2, at least 15 years)
gs_start_satellite: 500 m2 pixels - defined as the date whenMODIS EVI2 first crossed 15% of the segment EVI2 amplitude greenness
gs_end_satellite: 500 m2 pixels - defined as the date whenMODIS EVI2 last fell below 10% or 50% of the segment EVI2 amplitude greenness
ifyouthink_no_why: they did not explore link between GSL and growth. Instead, they looked at the relationship between growth (GPP) in the early and late part of the growing season and EOS.
ifyes_whichendogenous: greater GPP early in the growing season is associated with earlier EOS
excellent_study: no - not for our purposes. there are some really interesting patterns and lots of data, but in the end does not say much about the question we are interested in because there is a lot that isn't measured and in some cases could have been. The Zohner paper is really relevant to understanding how climate influences the end of season (EOS), as defined by remote sensing data (greenness declines in northern forests), the timing of leaf abscission / senescence (from phenological observations), and the decline of chlorophyll content in leaves of beech. However, they don't directly explore temperature effects on growth responses, but instead explore the effects of photosynthesis / productivity pre and post solstic on EOS... Of course, satellite data and PEP data also don't include growth measurements, so that would have been tough (although maybe they could have done something clever with NDVI integrated under the curve, or with ITRDB data for the PEP analysis), but they coudl certainly have done a better job with their experiment. They also focus entirely on EOS, so it's not always clear how the entire growing season length changes. They do use estimates of photosynthesis to calculate GPP, but they use it as an explanatory rather than a response variable.
big_problems: Both EOS and GPP were derived from MODIS, so seems problematic to put both in explanatory and response variable
missing_something_major: For all data sets reported on, I really wished they had done two things. A. Calculated and explored how the length of the growing season, rather than just the end of the season, varied; and B. Conducted analyses assessing the effects of the length of the growing season on the growth metric, rather than the opposite (their measures of growth, which were modeled or measured photosynthesis, were always considered as explanatory variables rather than response variables).
notes: see figures 2 and 3  in the manuscript; S1, S3 in the supplement
notes_specific_columns: biome column: mixed, broadleaf deciduous, evergreen needleleaf, or deciduous needleleaf forest; study_type: I went with synthesis because they were pulling together data from satellite-derived products (inputs to which are images but also other information - e.g. temperature models, land cover); growth_metric column: comes from function including MODIS fpar (fraction of photosynthetic radiation absorbed) and other environmental variables (including land cover, temperature, VPD); gls_metric column: MODIS EV1; gs_end_satellite column: used 2 metrics - EOS10 and EOS50; ifyes_whichexternal column: explored the relationship between mean daily temperature at the monthly level and EOS
gslxgrowthsimple: vegtative phenology x putative C assimilation

species_list: Aesculus hippocastanum, Betula pendula, Fagus sylvatic, Quercus robur
rep_number: 396,411 phenological observations, 12,759 individual time series from 1951–2015
ifyouthink_no_why: they did not explore link between GSL and growth. Instead, they looked at the relationship between photosynthesis in the early and late part of the growing season and the end of the season as defined by vegetative phenology metrics
ifyes_whichendogenous: greater photosynthesis early in the growing season is associated with earlier senescence, while greater photosynthesis late in the growing season is associated with later senescence
big_problems: The modeled photosynthesis products are hard to interpret
missing_something_major: For all data sets reported on, I really wished they had done two things. A. Calculated and explored how the length of the growing season, rather than just the end of the season, varied; and B. Conducted analyses assessing the effects of the length of the growing season on the growth metric, rather than the opposite (their measures of growth, which were modeled or measured photosynthesis, were always considered as explanatory variables rather than response variables).
notes: see figure 4 in the manuscript, S15 and S16 in the supplement
notes_specific_columns: study_type: I went with repeated measurements on observations since phenology data (PEP) is where they got their response variable, autumn senescence from. Given that the response variables are derived from many other sources (e.g. modeled photosynthesis, temperature) synthesis could also work. ifyes_whichexternal column: explored the relationship between mean daily temperature at the monthly level and autumn senescence, exploring month long windows before and after the solstice
gslxgrowthsimple: vegtative phenology x putative C assimilation

species_list: Acer pennsylvanicum, Acer rubrum, Acer saccharum, Betula allegheniensis, Betula lenta, Fagus grandifolia, Nyssa sylvatica, Quercus alba, Quercus rubra, Quercus velutina
ifyouthink_no_why: they did not explore the link between their growing season metric and growth
big_problems: I reported no for endogenous factors, but this could be wrong. Fig S4A has a discrepancy between what is reported in the figure legend (which states that the effects of monthly photosynthesis are explored) and the methods (which describes testing for the effects of temperature). If the legend is right, then they also explored the effects of endogenous factors for this data set and found that this did influence leaf senescence.
missing_something_major: For all data sets reported on, I really wished they had done two things. A. Calculated and explored how the length of the growing season, rather than just the end of the season, varied; and B. Conducted analyses assessing the effects of the length of the growing season on the growth metric, rather than the opposite (their measures of growth, which were modeled or measured photosynthesis, were always considered as explanatory variables rather than response variables).
notes: see figure S4 in the supplement
notes_specific_columns: study_type: I went with repeated measurements on individuals

youthink_evidence_gsxgrowth_notsure: it does appear that there is a weak relationship between growting season length and growth for FS and QP but the study was more interested in phenological rank
notes: They're more interested in phenological ranks and how earlier leafout species take advantage of early spring resources and grow more and then later leafout species have end of season resources and grow more but they did find a weak relationship between longer gsl and growth for two out of the three species
